docs.lead_paragraph: CHEMISTRY students in Lacey Township down in South Jersey will get a head start on their periodic tables this year. If they didn't know that K stands for potassium, they'll learn soon. That's because Lacey is among the state's school districts to stock up this year on potassium iodide -- or KI -- otherwise known as antiradiation pills. The pills are supplied by the state in case the Oyster Creek nuclear power plant nearby is attacked by terrorists -- or accidentally melts down -- on an otherwise routine school day. This year, nuclear fallout is only one of the many troubling circumstances that schools must be ready to deal with.

headline.main: Oh, When Schools Feared Only Nuclear Blasts

docs.abstract: Debra Galant Jersey column, recalling time when baby boomers were taught to crouch in school hallways to prepare for nuclear attack, on preparations that her children's schools are making in event of terrorist attacks, kidnappings, child suicides or other emergencies; drawing (M)
